title: Welcome to Central Tendencies
text: Welcome to my blog - Central Tendencies. My name is Benjamin Draves and I’m a Senior Applied Scientist at Uber in NYC. I received my Ph.D. in Statistics from Boston University and a B.S. in Mathematics from Lafayette College. The purpose of Central Tendencies is to share what I am reading, thinking about, and working on in hope of starting conversations with fellow statisticians and data scientists.

title: About Me
text:
My name is Benjamin Draves and I’m a Senior Applied Scientist at Uber in NYC. I work in our marketing science organization building recommendation and targeting machine learning systems to grow Uber’s consumer and earner business.
Before Uber, I received my Ph.D. in Statistics from Boston University and wrote my dissertation on spectral embedding methods for multiple network data and continue to study network science and matrix analysis methods. Outside of work, I enjoy distance running, soccer, and exploring NYC.

Data Sceince Topics that Excite Me
The purpose for Central Tendancies is to share what I am reading, working on, and thinking about. My interests vary but mainly center around three areas:

applied and theoretical statistics
machine learning
statistical pedagogy

My hope is this project serve to educate myself and others in these areas where

title: Central Tendancies
text:
Central Tendancies
The purpose for Central Tendancies is to share what I am reading, working on, and thinking about. My interests vary but center around:

applied and theoretical statistics
machine learning
statistical pedagogy

My goal for this project is to document and share my learnings with the hope of starting conversations with fellow statisticians and data scientists.

title: Welcome to Central Tendencies
text:
Current Projects

Reading





I am currently reading The Data Detective: Ten Easy Rules to Make Sense of Statistics by Tim Harford. Tim Harford is a well known economist and journalist who is excellent at finding and highlighting examples of common statistical misconceptions and pitfalls. I picked up this book because I knew it was likely chucked full of interesting examples of common statistical fallacies that are always useful for an applied statistician.


Thinking About

title: Welcome to Central Tendencies
text:
What I am currently…

Reading





I am currently reading The Data Detective: Ten Easy Rules to Make Sense of Statistics by Tim Harford. Tim Harford is a well known economist and journalist who is excellent at finding and highlighting examples of common statistical misconceptions and pitfalls. I picked up this book because I knew it was likely chucked full of interesting examples of common statistical fallacies that are always useful for an applied statistician.


Thinking About
I am currently thinking about the
I am thinking a lot about the history of statistics and how it intersects with how we teach statistics.
